questions.prompt: Which sorting algorithm repeatedly finds the minimum element and places it at the beginning?
questions.explanation: Selection Sort works by selecting the minimum element from the unsorted portion and swapping it with the first unsorted element.

questions.prompt: What is the average-case time complexity of Quick Sort?
questions.explanation: Quick Sort has an average-case complexity of O(n log n) when pivots divide the array reasonably well.

questions.prompt: Merge Sort is a stable sorting algorithm.
questions.explanation: Merge Sort preserves the relative order of equal elements, making it stable.

questions.prompt: Which sorting algorithm is most efficient for nearly-sorted data?
questions.explanation: Insertion Sort runs in O(n) time on nearly-sorted data because elements need minimal shifting.

questions.prompt: The space complexity of Merge Sort is O(___).
questions.explanation: Merge Sort requires O(n) auxiliary space to merge the sorted subarrays.

questions.prompt: What causes Quick Sort to degrade to O(n^2) time complexity?
options: Choosing the first element as pivot on sorted data
questions.explanation: When the pivot is always the smallest or largest element (e.g., first element on sorted data), partitions become unbalanced.

questions.prompt: After one pass of Bubble Sort (left to right), what is guaranteed?
questions.codeSnippet:
arr = [5, 3, 8, 4, 2]
# One pass of bubble sort
options: The smallest element is at position 0
The largest element is at the last position
questions.explanation: Bubble Sort "bubbles up" the largest element to the end after each complete pass.

questions.prompt: Heap Sort is a stable sorting algorithm.
questions.explanation: Heap Sort is not stable because the heap operations can change the relative order of equal elements.

questions.prompt: Which algorithm has the best worst-case time complexity?
questions.explanation: Merge Sort has O(n log n) worst-case, while Quick Sort can degrade to O(n^2) and Bubble/Insertion are O(n^2).

questions.prompt: What is the primary advantage of Heap Sort over Merge Sort?
questions.explanation: Heap Sort sorts in-place using only O(1) extra space, while Merge Sort requires O(n) auxiliary space.

questions.prompt: What sorting algorithm does this represent?
questions.explanation: This is Insertion Sort - it takes each element and inserts it into its correct position in the sorted portion.

questions.prompt: Python's built-in sort() uses which algorithm?
questions.explanation: Python uses Timsort, a hybrid of Merge Sort and Insertion Sort, optimized for real-world data.

questions.prompt: Selection Sort performs the minimum number of swaps among O(n^2) sorting algorithms.
questions.explanation: Selection Sort makes exactly n-1 swaps (one per pass), which is optimal for minimizing writes.

questions.prompt: When sorting records where maintaining original order of equal elements matters, which should you use?
questions.explanation: When stability matters (preserving order of equal elements), use a stable sort like Merge Sort.

questions.prompt: The technique of choosing the median of three elements as pivot in Quick Sort helps avoid ______ case performance.
questions.explanation: Median-of-three pivot selection helps avoid the worst case of O(n^2) on sorted or reverse-sorted input.
